thread.title: Service installers win back pay from DirecTV in court case
thread.title_full: Service installers win back pay from DirecTV in court case | The Seattle Times

author: Rachel Lerman
title: Service installers win back pay from DirecTV in court case
text:
DirecTV must disburse $395,000 in back pay to workers in Washington state to compensate 147 employees for hours they worked as service installers, a federal court has decided. 
The consent judgment in U.S. District Court for Western Washington came after the U.S. Department of Labor found the satellite TV company and its Kent-based subcontractor in violation of the Fair Labor Standards Act. The Department of Labor said installers were not paid for every hour they worked, were not paid overtime and did not get paid for travel time. 
The DOL took the issue to court in 2012, suing DirecTV and subcontractor Advanced Information Systems of Kent. The parties reached an agreement this month that requires DirecTV to comply with the fair labor act and to review agreements with its contractors across the country. 
DirecTV first stated it did not employ the installers, but rather the subcontractor did. The court found that DirecTV was a joint employer of the workers. 
  “This ruling represents major victory for workers’ rights in a landmark case against unacceptable fissuring practices used to avoid liability and responsibility in the workplace,” said Janet Herold, the DOL’s regional solicitor.
DirecTV said it does not believe it violated the fair labor act.
“While we believe we, and our current third-party contractors, have fully complied with the wage and hour laws in our DirecTV operations in Washington, we are pleased to put this dispute behind us,” a DirecTV representative said in a statement.
